text.title: Iraq dominates Blair-Berlusconi talks

main.p: Tony Blair today held a mini-summit in Rome with the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, which was dominated by recent bombing attacks in Iraq.

Although the ostensible purpose of the meeting was to discuss further privatisation within the EU - most notably in the fields of energy and telecommunications - the two coalition partners in Iraq met in Rome under the shadow of this week's massive bombing attacks.
Following their meeting, Mr Blair told reporters after his talks with Mr Berlusconi: "We are trying to work with the Iraqi people to put the country on its feet.
"The purpose of the terrorism is to stop that happening, is to try and cause religious division, hatred, so that Iraq cannot make that journey of progress.

"The terrorists know that if we manage to put Iraq on its feet that is a blow to the whole of their extremism, to that fundamental case against not just the western world but moderate Arab countries too.
"The struggle that's happening is a struggle that literally will be of fundamental importance to the future of the Middle East and to the future of the world.

And he dismissed the notion that Iraq was plunging into civil war, saying: "A civil war is two parts of a country in hostility to one another. This isn't what's happening in Iraq. The vast majority of people there want to work together.
"There's no reason why they can't make this political progress."

Mr Blair and Mr Berlusconi also agreed to write a joint letter to Ireland's taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, who currently holds the EU's rotating presidency, stressing the need for continuing economic reform.
The prime minister also stressed Britain's relations with Italy were as strong as they have ever been, with an Anglo-Italian summit to be held this summer.
Mr Blair was flying back to London tonight.

The meeting was also, at least in part, a bridge-building exercise by the British prime minister, after Mr Berlusconi felt aggrieved at being left out of the informal "trilateral" summit of Britain, France and Germany last month.
The Italian leader, freshly recovered from an alleged facelift over the Christmas break, has said he would reject any moves from the so-called Big Three that Italy did not approve of.
